how_calculated: Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 37 weeks gestation among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 37 weeks gestation among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing gestational age among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 32 weeks gestation among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of live, singleton births occurring at less than 32 weeks gestation among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing gestational age among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.
Number of live, singleton births with a birthweight less than 1,500 grams (3 lbs 5 oz) among residents of an area. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of live, singleton births with a birthweight less than 1,500 grams (3 lbs 5 oz) among residents of an area, divided by the number of live, singleton births with nonmissing birthweight among residents of the area; expressed as percent. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of live, singleton, term births with a birthweight less than 2,500 grams (5 lbs, 8 oz) among residents of an area. Term births are those with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of live, singleton, term births with a birthweight less than 2,500 grams (5 lbs 8 oz) among residents of an area, divided by the total number of live, singleton, term births with nonmissing birthweight among residents of the area; expressed as percent. All births are restricted to those with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of deaths occurring at less than 1 year of age. Infant deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of deaths occurring at less than 1 year of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed as cases per 1,000 live births. Infant deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of deaths occurring at less than 28 days of age in an area. For more information about this measure, click here. Neonatal deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth.

Number of deaths occurring at less than 28 days of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed as cases per 1,000 live births. Neonatal deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of fetal deaths occurring at 28 or more weeks gestation, plus infant deaths occurring up to 6 days after birth in an area. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of fetal deaths occurring at 28 or more weeks gestation, plus infant deaths occurring up to 6 days after birth, divided by the sum of fetal deaths at 28 weeks or more gestation and live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed per 1,000 fetal deaths plus live births. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of deaths occurring from 28 days to less than 1 year of age in an area. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of deaths occurring from 28 days to less than 1 year of age in an area, divided by the number of live births among resident mothers of the area; expressed per 1,000 live births. Deaths are restricted to those that can be linked to a birth certificate of a NYC resident mother and are mapped to the mother's usual residence at birth. For more information about this measure, click here.

Sum of annual age-specific birth rates (grouped by 5-year age intervals, from 10 - 49 years) among NYC resident women, multiplied by 5; expressed per 1,000 women. For more information about this measure, click here.

Number of male births divided by the number of female births among resident mothers of the area. Births are restricted to singletons with a gestational age of 37 weeks or more. For more information about this measure, click here.

Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.
Estimated number of people born outside the US or its territories (which includes Puerto Rico), divided by the total population; expressed as a percent.
Estimated number of housing units with more than 1 occupant per room, divided by the number of occupied housing units; expressed as percent.
Number of housing units built before 1950.
Number of housing units built before 1950, divided by all housing units; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of housing units occupied by the owner, divided by all occupied housing units; expressed as percent.

Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma and symptoms in the last 12 months, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.

Estimated number of adults aged 18 years and older who reported medically diagnosed asthma with symptoms in the last 12 months, divided by all adults and adjusted for age; expressed as percent. Beginning in 2017, indicator includes data imputed for missing responses.
Estimated number of children up to 17 years  old whose parent or guardian reported medically diagnosed asthma and symptoms in the last 12 months, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of children up to 17 years old whose parent or guardian reported medically diagnosed asthma and symptoms in the last 12 months, divided by all children; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households that reported personal use of pesticide sprays, bombs, or foggers, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of households in an area that reported personal use of pesticide sprays, bombs, or foggers, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households that reported personal use of the pesticide Tempo, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of households in an area that reported personal use of the pesticide Tempo, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of respondents in an area that reported cockroaches in the past 30 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of respondents in an area that reported cockroaches in the past 30 days, divided by the number of respondents in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats outside their building in the past 90 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of adults reporting mice or rats outside their building in the past 90 days, divided by the number of adults in the area; expressed as percent.

Estimated number of adults exposed to second-hand smoke at home, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.

Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
Number of carbon monoxide incidents where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene.
Number of carbon monoxide incidents in an area, where FDNY measured at least 1 ppm at the scene, divided by the number of buildings in the area; expressed as incidents per 10,000 buildings.
Estimated number of households that reported cracks or holes in the home.
Estimated number of households in an area that reported cracks or holes in the home, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint in areas greater than 8.5" x 11".

Estimated number of households in an area that were built before 1960 and had peeling paint n areas greater than 8.5" x 11", divided by the total number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households in an area that reported leaks coming from outside the unit, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households in an area that reported leaks coming from outside the unit, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households that are near buildings with broken or boarded up windows (based on observation).
Estimated number of households in an area that are near buildings with broken or boarded up windows (based on observation), divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households in deteriorating or dilapidated buildings.
Estimated number of households in an area in deteriorated or dilapidatied buildings, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.

Estimated number of households reporting three or more maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit).

Estimated number of households in an area reporting three or more maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8½ x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit), divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households that rated their neighborhood structures as good or excellent.
Estimated number of households in an area that rated their neighborhood structures as good or excellent, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households that needed to use a secondary source of heat in addition to their primary source.
Estimated number of households in an area that needed to use a secondary source of heat in addition to their primary source, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households that reported regular exterminator service.
Estimated number of households in an area that reported regular exterminator service, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of households that reported mice or rats in their building in the past 90 days.
Estimated number of households in an area that reported mice or rats in their building in the past 90 days, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
When the daily average ozone levels are above 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for the General Population".
This measure is calculated by averaging PM2.5 levels at each monitor, weighted by the number of samples in each quarter, then taking the weighted average of all monitors in the geographic area.
Average annual number of female residents, less than 50 yrs old, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by 5.

Average annual number of female residents, less than 50 yrs old, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.
Average annual number of female residents, 50 yrs and older, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by 5.

Average annual number of female residents, 50 Yrs and Older, diagnosed with breast cancer over the 5 year period, divided by the corresponding age-specific intercensal population estimates (from NYS DOH). The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Average Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 female residents.

Number of calls to the NYC Poison Control Center for reported unintentional human exposure to carbon monoxide.

Number of calls to the NYC Poison Control Center for reported unintentional human exposure to carbon monoxide, divided by the population in the area using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.
Number of residential units in one or two family homes as identified by NYC Department of City Planning, divided by all residential units; expressed as a percent.

Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children up to 4 years old. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident youths and adults (15 years and older).

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.

Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident youths and adults (15 years and older), divided by the population of youth and adults (15 years and older) using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.

Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident youths and adults (15 years and older) summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or any of the following: E868.2, E868.3, E868.8, E868.9. Must also have an unintentional fire-related injury code within E890.0-E899.9.  Cannot have any intentional injury code E950.0-E969.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or any of the following: E868.2, E868.3, E868.8, E868.9. Must also have an unintentional fire-related injury code within E890.0-E899.9. Cannot have any intentional injury code E950.0-E969. Count is divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per million residents.

NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or any of the following: E868.2, E868.3, E868.8, E868.9. Must also have an unintentional fire-related injury code within E890.0-E899.9. Cannot have any intentional injury code E950.0-E969. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per million residents.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or any of the following: E868.2, E868.3, E868.8, E868.9. Must not have any fire-related injury code E890.0-E899.9, nor any intentional injury code E950.0-E969.  Acceptable injury codes in range: E800.0-E888.9, E900.0-E909.9.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or any of the following: E868.2, E868.3, E868.8, E868.9. Must not have any fire-related injury code E890.0-E899.9, nor any intentional injury code E950.0-E969. Acceptable injury codes in range: E800.0-E888.9, E900.0-E909.9. Count is divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per million residents.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or any of the following: E868.2, E868.3, E868.8, E868.9. Must not have any fire-related injury code E890.0-E899.9, nor any intentional injury code E950.0-E969. Acceptable injury codes in range: E800.0-E888.9, E900.0-E909.9. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per million residents.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or either of the following codes for unknown reason E982.0, or E982.1. Must not have any fire-related injury code E890.0-E899.9, nor any intentional injury code E950.0-E969.  Includes 986 without any E-code.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or either of the following codes for unknown reason E982.0, or E982.1. Must not have any fire-related injury code E890.0-E899.9, nor any intentional injury code E950.0-E969. Includes 986 without any E-code. Count is divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per million residents.

Number of NYC resident hospitalizations containing ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, or either of the following E982.0 or E982.1. Must not have any fire-related injury code E890.0-E899.9, nor any intentional injury code E950.0-E969. Includes 986 without any E-code. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per million residents.

Number of NYC resident adults 35 to 64 years hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction). A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.

Number of NYC resident adults 35 to 64 years hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction) divided by the population 65 years and older; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.

Number of NYC resident adults 35 to 64 years old hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction), summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.

An AQI value of 100 corresponds to the current U.S. standard for a pollutant (0.075 ppm for ozone, 35 ug/m3 for PM2.5), and deviations from the standard are expressed as the pollutant concentration divided by the standard and multiplied by 100. Advisory days for the general public are counted when either ozone or PM2.5 levels are above 150.

An AQI value of 100 corresponds to the current U.S. standard for a pollutant (0.075 ppm for ozone, 35 ug/m3 for PM2.5), and deviations from the standard are expressed as the pollutant concentration divided by the standard and multiplied by 100. Advisory days for sensitive groups are counted when either ozone or PM2.5 levels are above 100.
Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, mechanical, or termiticide.
Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, "mechanical", or termiticide.
Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that are classified as rodenticide.

Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as fertilizer, herbicide, defoliant, herbicide terrestrial, herbicide aquatic, or plant growth regulator.

Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as fertilizer, herbicide, defoliant, herbicide terrestrial, herbicide aquatic, or plant growth regulator.

Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as fungistat, fungicide, fungicide/fungistat, or fungicide/nematicide. Excludes products classified as disinfectant, sanitizer, microbicide, microbicide/microbistat, insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide.

Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class organophosphorous compound.

Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class organophosphorous compound.

Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class pyrethrin or pyrethroid.

Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class pyrethrin or pyrethroid.

Sum of gallons of liquid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredient of the chemical class N-methyl carbamate

Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; and containing active ingredients of the chemical class N-methyl carbamate

Sum of pounds of solid pesticide applications that meet the following qualifications: classified as insect growth regulator, insecticide, miticide, or termiticide; having the term bait or gel in the product name, or containing active ingredients boric acid, disodium octaborate tetrahydrate, sodium tetraborate (pentahydrate), indoxacarb, silica gel, diatomaceous earth, (Z)-9-tricosene, S-methoprene, spinosad, hydramethylnon, pyriproxyfen, or fipronil; and not containing active ingredients of the chemical classes pyrethrins, pyrethroids, N-methyl carbamates or organophosphorous compounds.

Estimated number of people for whom poverty status is determined, whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level, divided by the number of people for whom poverty status is determined; expressed as percent.

Estimated number of households in an area that reported seeing at least one cockroach daily over the last month, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.

The NYC Department of Transportation (DOT) has under its purview 842 bridges. Federal and State law require that bridges be inspected a minimum of every two years. New York State performs the actual bridge inspections and assigns a numerical rating. The NYC DOT then translates those ratings to the verbal designations of "very good," "good," "fair" or "poor." This indicator is the percent of bridges rated as either "very good", "good", or "fair".

The NYC DOT Street Assessment Unit conducts an annual pavement condition survey that assesses conditions for one half of New York City streets. The entire city is evaluated once every two years. Street Assessment inspectors rate individual city streets on a scale of 1 through 10 (1 being the worst and 10 being the best). Any street that receives a rating of 7 or below is eligible for resurfacing, whereas any street with a rating of 8 through 10 is not eligible and is in a state of good repair. Reported are the percentages of streets rating between 8 and 10.

The number of subway stations for which infrastructure components are replaced on a schedule consistent with its life expectancy. The indicator tracks how many stations have been renovated by the end of their expected useful life, expressed as a percentage.

The percentage of the census block area that falls within 1/4 mile of a park edge in a given year, multiplied by the total population of the Census block, summed for all census blocks, then expressed as a percent of 2000 Census population.

The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.
The total is divided by the NYC intercensal population estimates, which are calculated by the US Census Bureau and then verified by the NYC Department of City Planning.

The average daily number of gallons of drinking water diverted to in-city supply over the course of the year. This amount is divided by the NYC intercensal population estimates, which are calculated by the US Census Bureau and then verified by the NYC Department of City Planning.

The cumulative sum of the number of Certificates of Occupancy, including Temporary Certificates of Occupancy, issued annually by the Department of Buildings since the inception of PlaNYC in 2007. A Certificate of Occupancy is required by the City and indicates that a building is ready for occupation.
The number of housing units in NYC is derived from the Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS), which is a triennial, population-based, cross-sectional survey of housing units in NYC.

For each year of Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS) data, a housing budget is calculated by taking the estimated citywide median household income for all households (from the HVS), divided by 12 months, and multiplied by 0.3. The estimated percentage of rental units (occupied and vacant/available for rent) with an asking rent (contract) less than or equal to the derived maximum housing budget are counted as affordable to the typical NYC household. This measure incorporates changes in median household income as well as changes in asking rent.

Estimated citywide number of vacant or available for rent units in the lowest rent category (<$700 real 2008 dollars), divided by the citywide estimate of total rental units (occupied and available for rent) in that category.

The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.
The total is divided by the gross city product (GCP); expressed in millions of 2005 dollars.

The percentage of new building permits for residential units issued annually by the Department of Buildings that are located within a 1/2 mile radius of a transit node (e.g., subway stop, commuter rail station).

The number of pounds of CO2e produced by all NYC sources of electricity, divided by the citywide electric energy usage in megawatt-hours. The amount of CO2e that an electricity source will produce depends on the fuel that is burned and loss that occurs within the distribution network. CO2 equivalents include both emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of greenhouse gases of other greenhouse gases. These gases include methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs) and sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), each of which has a specific global warming potential (potential to trap heat in Earth's atmosphere). All six greenhouse gases are converted to CO2e and added together to report in one common unit.

The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.

The number of metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) emitted by NYC buildings (direct emissions from combustion of fuel oil and natural gas, indirect emissions from generation of electricity and steam); transportation (direct emissions from buses, commuter rail, trucks, and passenger cars, and indirect emissions from electricity for mass transit); and indirect emissions from generation of electricity used in streetlights and traffic signals; together with fugitive and process emissions (from solid waste management, electricity distribution, wastewater treatment, and vehicle cooling). CO2 equivalent includes emissions of CO2 as well as an equivalent amount of CO2 (in terms of global warming impact) of other greenhouse gases, including methane, nitrous oxide, hydroflourocarbons, perfluorocarbons, and sulfur hexafluoride. Each gas is converted to CO2e, based on its potential to trap heat in the Earth's atmosphere, and emissions from all six gases are added together for reporting in one common unit.
The number for each year is expressed as a percentage of 2005 base output. When the city has met its goal of a 30% reduction, this indicator will read "70".

The amount of fuel oil, electricity, natural gas, and steam power used in the City's building stock is converted to MMBTU and then divided by the City population. Because a hotter or colder summer or winter can have a significant impact on energy usage, this metric lessens the effects of weather by calculating a 3 year rolling average of energy usage for each year.

The annual average dissolved oxygen concentration (mg/L) across Harbor Survey stations. There is a NYS standard of 5.0mg/L necessary to allow bathing, in addition to a less stringent standard to allow fishing and boating. A higher number indicates a cleaner harbor.

The number of NYC drinking water analyses that are below the NYS maximum contaminant level (MCL) for 227 different contaminants tested throughout the year, divided by the total number of analyses performed throughout the year; expressed as a percent, with a maximum value of 100%. The NYC Department of Environmental Protection performs over 10,000 drinking water analyses monthly.

The annual geometric mean of fecal coliform counts across Harbor Survey stations. The state standard to allow bathing is a monthly geometric mean less than or equal to 200 cells / 100mL (from 5 or more samples). There is a less stringent standard to allow fishing and boating.

Automobile traffic is calculated by summing data reported in the New York Metropolitan Transportation Council's (NYMTC) annual hub-bound (Manhattan below 60th St) report, the NYC Department of Transportation?s (DOT) screenline reports, and annual bridge traffic data. The NYMTC and NYC DOT traffic and screenline reports are manual counts that are modeled in order to extrapolate throughout the year. Transit ridership is calculated from NYC transit subway and bus boarding data, and includes bicycle ridership as estimated from NYC DOT bicycle screenline (boundary) counts and NYMTC annual hub-bound reports. Both numbers are indexed so that their volume percentage in the year 2000 equals 100.

Number of trips to the central business district (Manhattan below 60th street) on a typical fall morning by transit (bus, subway, railroad, passenger ferry, tram) or bicycle, divided by the total number of automobile, taxi, van and truck trips; expressed as a percent.

The total number of miles (in millions) that transit (public transportation) vehicles (subway cars, rail cars, buses, ferry boats, van pools, trams, para-transit vehicles) are scheduled to travel or actually travel while in revenue service. This number combines all transit agencies in the New York metropolitan area, including non-city agencies that provide significant transit service to and from the city (e.g., Long Island Rail Road). Vehicle revenue miles do not include situations when a bus or subway car travels without passengers back to a storage depot.
Estimated number of adults in an area without a policy that prohibits smoking anywhere in the home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
Estimated number of adults without a policy that prohibits smoking anywhere in the home, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of adults who report current, active smoking, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of adults in an area who report current, active smoking, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.

Estimated number of adults exposed to second-hand smoke at work, rounded to the nearest 1,000. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time at work are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at work.

Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at work, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent. Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time at work are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at work.
Estimated number of high school students who smoked cigarettes on one or more of the past 30 days, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of high school students who smoked cigarettes on one or more of the past 30 days, divided by total number of high school students; expressed as a percent.
Average annual number of residents diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia over the 5 year period.

ConEdison calculates a System Average Interruption Frequency Index (SAIFI) on an annual basis, which gauges the relative reliability of the NYC electricity network. It does so by measuring the average number of service interruptions per 1000 customers in a given year.

The resulting age-specific rates are multiplied by the proportion of the US Census 2000 standard population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of these weighted rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.

Samples are collected from entry points to the drinking water distribution system. Samples may not be required every year; the most recent available sample result is used to calculate the average. If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year and compared to the Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL), which is the highest level of a contamimant that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.

Samples are collected from entry points to the drinking water distribution system. Samples may not be required every year; the most recent available sample result is used to calculate the maximum concentration. If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year and compared to the Maximum Contaminant Level (MCL), which is the highest level of a contamimant that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.
The number of nitrate samples taken at entry points to the distribution system.
Number of sampling locations.

Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year.

Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each year.
The number of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) samples taken throughout the distribution system.
Number of sampling total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) locations.

Samples are collected from entry points to the drinking water distribution system. Due to low levels of arsenic in NYC drinking water, samples may not be required every year; the most recent available sample result is used to calculate the average. If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over the year.

Number of NYC resident adults 65 years and older hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction). A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.

Number of NYC resident adults 65 years and older hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction) divided by the population 65 years and older; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.

Number of NYC resident adults 65 years and older hospitalized for heart attack (acute myocardial infarction), summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 410 or an ICD-10 rincipal diagnosis code of I21 or I22 and excluded if the patient was transfered from one urgrent care facility within NYC to another.

Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident youths and adults (15 years and older). 

 

An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify adult asthma, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.

Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those who were admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED, having an ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, and an unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. Cannot have any intentional injury code within E950.0-E979.9 or E990-E999.

NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those who were admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED, having an ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, and an unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. Cannot have any intentional injury code within E950.0-E979.9 or E990-E999. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per million residents.

NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those who were admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED, having an ICD-9 diagnosis code for carbon monoxide poisoning, 986, and an unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. Cannot have any intentional injury code within E950.0-E979.9 or E990-E999. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per million residents.

Count of deaths during months of May-September with ICD10 code of T67 as a contributing cause, with underlying or other cause of death X30 (excluding any records with man-made source of heat, W92). Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per million residents.

Number of deaths during warm season months of May-September with an underlying or contributing cause that includes excessive natural heat (ICD10 code X30) and effects of heat and light (ICD10 code T67), among NYC residents. This number includes only deaths directly attributed to heat on death certificates, which represent a small proportion of all heat-related deaths. Heat can exacerbate chronic conditions, resulting in death from natural causes that may not be labeled as heat-related on a death certificate (also called "excess mortality.")

The number of NYC residents treated in a NYC emergency department (ED) during the months of May-September for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of visit and include those with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases occuring before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.

The average number of vehicles traveling on a road segment on any given day during the year was estimated for each segment in a geography. The number of vehicles was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square kilometer.

The number of cars was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The average number of trucks traveling on a road segment on any given day during the year was estimated for each segment in a geography. The number of trucks was multiplied by length of road segment to arrive at a daily vehicle-miles measure for that segment. The daily vehicle-miles measures were summed across all segments in a geography and then multiplied by 365 to arrive at an annual measure. Vehicle-miles are expressed in millions per square kilomete

Estimate is based on the number of emergency department (ED) visits for asthma associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of emergency department visits for asthma from the Ito K et al 2007 study conducted on NYC residents. Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for respiratory causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all respiratory causes from the Moolgavkar 2000 study conducted on Los Angeles residents between 20-64 years of age and the Zanobetti et al 2009 study in 26 US communities of residents over 65 years of age. Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents over 20 years of Age.

Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for cardiovascular causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to natural background (modeled air quality levels under no man-made air pollution emissions). Neighborhood estimates expressed as annual cases per 100,000 residents over 40 years of age.

Estimate is calculated using the acute cardiorespiratory mortality risk estimate from Huang et al 2005 estimate of New York City risk. Z-scores were calculated and summed across indicators of residential population density (density of population per total residential land area); intersection density; an entropy measure of land use based on the distribution of building floor area among 5 land-use types (education, entertainment, residential (single- and multi-family), retail, and office); the ratio of retail building floor area to retail land area; and subway stop density. This scale is a variation of Frank's Walkability Index.

Counts are the number of NYC emergency department (ED) visits related to bicycle injuries among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM injury codes: V01-V99. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Citywide totals include both NYC residents and non-residents. Counts are summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64,65+0 and divided by the population of NYC residents in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Citywide totals include both NYC residents and non-residents. Counts are summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population of NYC residents in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

Tree canopy cover represents a 'top down' mapping perspective in which tree canopy over-hanging city features (such as sidewalks) is measured. The percent is calculated by dividing the area of tree canopy in km2 within the UHF neighborhood by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies).

Subway station density measure takes into account multiple route-transfer opportunities at one subway station and each stop is counted only once regardless of how many route-transfer opportunities are available at any given subway station. Density is calculated by dividing the count of MTA subways stations as of 2012 by the total land area in km2 of the UHF neighborhood (excluding inland water bodies).

NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of October-April for the effects of reduced temperature or excessive or extreme cold due to weather conditions or undetermined cause (International Classification of Diseases, 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 991, E901.0, E901.8, E901.9, or E988.3 if admitted before October 1, 2015; International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes X31, T68, T69, T33, T34 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Residents with a diagnostic code for excessive cold due to man-made conditions were excluded (ICD-9-CM code E901.1 if admitted before October 1, 2015; ICD-10-CM code W93 if admitted on or after October 1, 2015). Annual data is based on date of admission, and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of cold-related illness in any principal or other diagnostic field. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Counts are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

Note: Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.

Estimated number of renter-occupied households reporting no maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8? x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit).

Sidewalks are a critical component of New York City residents’ commute. Ample sidewalks in neighborhoods are important for commuting, businesses, and physical activity. Greater sidewalk area facilitates safer pedestrian traffic that, in turn, attracts businesses and fosters community. “Sidewalk area” measures the percent of a neighborhood that is covered by sidewalk area.

The total sidewalk area (curb-to-building) in km2 within the UHF neighborhood divided by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies). Higher percentages indicate greater sidewalk area, with zero representing no sidewalk area.

For more information, visit http://beh.columbia.edu/.

The physical disorder score was calculated from observations of Google Street View imagery from August 2007 to October 2011 of nine indicators of disorder in 532 blocks: bottles, litter, graffiti, poorly maintained buildings, burned out buildings, abandoned buildings, abandoned cars, vacant lots, and bars on windows. Scores have been multiplied by 10 for greater display of precision. Higher scores indicate more physical disorder.

For more information, visit http://beh.columbia.edu/.

Neighborhoods are categorized by percent of residents with incomes below 100% of the Federal Poverty Level as follows: <10% (low), 10% to < 20% (medium), 20% to < 30% (high) and 30% and higher (very high).

Number of children less than 6 years old tested in a given year with blood lead levels of 5 mcg/dL or greater. The numbers in this table include all children tested within a given calendar year, regardless of whether they were tested in previous years with the same or different blood lead levels. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, children are only counted once using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child?s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. This measure differs from the number of children newly identified with blood lead levels at or above a certain level reported by the Health Department in other publications.

Number of public school children, age 5-14 years, with a most recent asthma diagnosis reported to NYC DOHMH from the previous or current school year that describes symptoms occurring more than twice per week, divided by the 5-14 year old population, expressed per 1,000. Rates are calculated by residence of the child. Note: Use of a denominator consisting of all 5-14 year olds results in an underestimate of the true asthma prevalence, since the numerator represents only children enrolled in public schools that report to NYC DOHMH.

When the daily average PM2.5 levels are between 101 and 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for Sensitive Groups" (people with heart or lung disease, children, older adults and people of lower socieconomic status). Folks in these groups may need to take action to protect their health on these days. An AQI value of 100 generally corresponds to a pollution level that is equal to the daily federal air quality standard.
When the daily average PM2.5 levels are above 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for the General Population".

When the daily average ozone levels are between 101 and 150 on EPA's Air Quality Index (AQI), the day is an "Action Day for Sensitive Groups" (people with lung disease, children, older adults, people who are active outdoors or have certain genetic variants).

98% of PM2.5 measurements taken at New York City's EPA Air Quality Stations are below this value over the past three years. This value is one of the PM2.5 Federal Air Quality Standards. The standard is 65 mcg per cubic meter.

Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning and are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.

Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each quarter.
The highest level of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5) that is allowed in drinking water, according to regulatory standards.

Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of trichloroacetic acid, dichloroacetic acid, monochloroacetic acid, dibromoacetic acid and monobromoacetic acid are summed within samples to derive a measure of total haloacetic acids (five) (HAA5). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged for each quarter.
The highest level of TTHM that is allowed in drinking water according to regulatory standards

Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. Total concentrations are averaged over each quarter.

Samples are collected from the drinking water distribution system, and concentrations of chloroform, bromodichloromethane, dibromochloromethane, and bromoform are summed within samples to derive a measure of total trihalomethane (TTHM). If a concentration is below the limit of detection (LOD), a value equal to one half the LOD is assigned. The maximum total concentration is identified for each quarter.
The highest level of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) that is allowed in drinking water according to regulatory standards.

The number of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) samples taken throughout the distribution system.

The number of total trihalomethanes (TTHM) samples taken throughout the distribution system.

Number of fatal work-related injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Census of Fatal Occupational Injuries. CFOI produces statistics on fatal work-related injuries by cross-referencing multiple sources, such as death certificates, workers' compensation reports, and Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) investigation reports.
Number of fatal work-related injuries occurring in NYC and reported to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, divided by the size of the NYC workforce, expressed as deaths per 10,000 workers.

Sum of the number of children under 6 years of age with blood lead levels (BLL) 5 mcg/dL or greater over the time period, divided by the number of years in the time period. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, for this measure children are only counted once per year using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.

  • For the purpose of providing data for small geographic areas, multiple years of data were combined to get sufficient numbers of observations to make more reliable estimates for a greater number of neighborhood tabulation areas (NTAs).
  • Annual numbers and rates of children under 6 years of age with elevated blood lead levels at the citywide, borough, and United Hospital Fund neighborhood level are available here.

Average annual number of children under 6 years of age tested for lead poisoning. Children may be tested multiple times in a given year but for this measure are only counted once per year. All children are counted regardless of blood specimen type (confirmed or unconfirmed). Numbers are rounded to nearest 10. Read more about definitions and measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.

Number of children under 6 years of age tested with blood lead levels (BLL) 5 mcg/dL or greater, divided by the total number of children under 6 years of age who were tested; expressed as cases per 1,000 tested. While children can receive more than one test during the calendar year, for this measure children are only counted once per year using the highest confirmed blood lead level during the calendar year. If the child does not have a confirmed test in a given year, the child’s blood lead level is based on the highest capillary or unknown test type. Read more about different measures used by the Health Department for surveillance of childhood lead poisoning.

  • For the purpose of providing data for small geographic areas, multiple years of data were combined to get sufficient numbers of observations to make more reliable estimates for a greater number of neighborhood tabulation areas (NTAs). 
  • Annual numbers and rates of children under 6 years of age with elevated blood lead levels at the citywide, borough, and United Hospital Fund neighborhood level are available here.

 RDI = 1 – (P2 Asian + P2 Black + P2 Hispanic + P2 White)

Estimated number of people in the civilian labor force (16 years and older) who are unemployed. All civilians 16 years old and over are classified as unemployed if they (1) were neither "at work" nor "with a job but not at work" during the reference week, and (2) were looking for work during the last 4 weeks, and (3) were available to accept a job. Also included as unemployed are civilians who did not work at all during the reference week, were waiting to be called back to a job from which they had been laid off, and were available for work except for temporary illness.

Number of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)-related hospitalizations among NYC residents aged 25 years and older, summed within 5-year age groups, and divided by the population in each age group using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. Hospitalizations include ICD-9 principal diagnosis codes 490 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), 491 (chronic bronchitis), 492 (emphysema), 496 (chronic airway obstruction, not elsewhere classified), 493.2 (chronic obstructive asthma) or ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes J40 (bronchitis, not specified as acute or chronic), J41-J42 (chronic bronchitis), J43 (emphysema), or J44 (other COPD). Cases with 493.2 are excluded if none of the secondary diagnosis fields contain 490-492 or 496. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems differ in how they classify COPD, data are not comparable before and after 2015. Data from 2015 are not shown because they contain a combination of ICD-9 and ICD-10 principal diagnosis codes.

Estimate is based on the number of emergency department (ED) visits for asthma associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of emergency department visits for asthma from the Ito K et al 2007 study conducted on NYC residents.

Estimate is based on the number of emergency department (ED) visits for asthma associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of emergency department visits for asthma from the Ito K et al 2007 study conducted on NYC residents.

Estimated annual number of all-cause deaths associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the chronic all-cause mortality risk estimate from a comprehensive study by Krewski et al 2009.

Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for cardiovascular causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to natural background (modeled air quality levels under no man-made air pollution emissions). Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all cardiovascular causes from the Ito K et al 2010 study conducted on New York City residents above 40 years of age.

Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for respiratory causes associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalizations for all respiratory causes from the Moolgavkar 2000 study conducted on Los Angeles residents between 20-64 years of age and the Zanobetti et al 2009 study in 26 US communities of residents over 65 years of age.

Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of emergency department visits for asthma from the Ito K et al 2007 study conducted on NYC residents.

Estimate is based on the number of hospitalizations for urgent asthma associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to natural background (modeled air quality levels under no man made air pollution emissions). Estimate is calculated using the acute risk of hospitalization for urgent asthma from the Silverman et al 2010 study conducted on NYC residents.

Estimate is based on the number of cardiovascular and respiratory mortalities associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the acute cardiorespiratory mortality risk estimate from Huang et al 2005 estimate of New York City risk.

Estimated annual number of all-cause deaths associated with the difference in air quality for indicator years relative to modeled natural background. Estimate is calculated using the chronic all-cause mortality risk estimate from a comprehensive study by Krewski et al 2009.

Number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only.

Rate of Non-fatal Assault Hospitalizations

Notes: Rates are age-adjusted to US Standard 2000 population and are pooled over 3 years.

Number of deaths during cold season months of October-April with an underlying or contributing cause that includes excessive natural cold (ICD10 code X31) and hypothermia (ICD10 code T68), among NYC residents. Number excludes deaths due to excessive cold of man-made origin (ICD10 code W93) and intentional deaths (ICD10 codes X6-X9, Y0, Y35, Y36).
Estimated number of households reporting someone using electric medical equipment, rounded to the nearest 1,000.
Estimated number of households reporting someone using electric medical equipment; expressed as percent.
Estiamted percent of people who are not White.

Average annual number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old, divided by the population of children up to 4 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Aggregated number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children up to 4 years old. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC resident children aged 5 to 17 years. ED visits include both patients who are treated and released in the ED (outpatients) and who are admitted as inpatients through the emergency department. An ED visit is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.

Number of asthma-related emergency department (ED) visits among NYC adults (18 years and older). Counts are the number of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only. Age-specific rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older.

Average Annual Number of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older was identified using the following ICD9-CM external cause of injury codes (E-codes): E880-E886, E888. Only live discharges are included. Citywide figures include NYC residents and non-residents; figures by borough and neighborhood of residence include NYC residents only.
The total curb-to-building sidewalk area in square kilometers within the UHF neighborhood divided by the total land area (excluding inland water bodies).

A map of "walk-to-a-park service areas" from the NYC Parks Department was overlayed onto a map of 2017 population estimates by census tract to calculate the percentage of the population that potentially live within the service area. These percentages were aggregated up to a neighborhood level.

The number of bodegas per supermarket within an area based on address of business. Bodegas are defined as food purchasing establishments with less than 4,000 square foot and excludes specialty stores, such as bakeries and vitamin stores. Supermarkets are defined as retail food purchasing establishments with greater than or equal to 10,000 square feet or have a chain supermarket name regardless of size.
Percentage of street mileage with conventional and protected bicycle lanes, not including sharrows, dirt trails, boardwalks, and velodromes.

Walking distance to a subway station is defined as 1/4-mile or less. Distance was measured between the centroid of 2010 Census blocks and the nearest station entrance. Census block populations within areas defined as walking distance were summed across the neighborhood and divided by total neighborhood population.

Number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only. Counts are the number of NYC non-fatal assault hospitalizations among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only. Counts are summed within five age groups (0-17, 18-24, 25-44, 45-64, 65+) and divided by the population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates, expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

Number of NYC nonfatal assault emergency department visits among all ages was identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: X92-X99, Y00-Y04, Y07-Y09, T(36-65).x3, T(36-65).xx3, T71.xx3, T74, T76. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. Assaults classified as terrorism, legal intervention, or operations of war are excluded. All figures include NYC residents only. Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

The number of NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code of T58 for accidental or undetermined-cause carbon monoxide poisoning and any fire-related code within the range of X00-X08. For all years, excludes records with intentional injury codes. Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
