For all years, excludes records with intentional injury codes. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Age-adjusted rates were calculated per 100,000 population 65 years and older weighted to the 2016 NYC DOHMH population estimates using the following age groups for weighting: 65-74, 75-84, and 85+ years old. Numerator consists of NYC hospitalizations related to falls among adults aged 65 years and older, identified using the following ICD10-CM codes: V00.1(1-5,8)1; V00.2(1,2,8)1; V00.3(1,2,8)1; V00.8(1-3,9)1; W00.0-W15; W16.0(1-3)2; W16.1(1-3)2; W16.3(1-3)2; W16.42x; W16.5(1-3)2; W16.6(1,2,7)2; W16.7(1,2)2; W16.8(1-3)2; W16.92x, W17; W18.1(1,2)x; W18.2xx; W18.3(0,1,9)x; W19. Only live discharges and initial encounters are included. All figures include NYC residents only.

The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September summed over a 5-year period for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department. Numbers are summed by 5-year age groups and divided by the 5-year summed population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates, to produce Average annualized rates. Quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. The Average annual Age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents. Notes: The coding system used to represent diagnoses changed in October 2015. Cases admitted before October 1, 2015 are represented by International Classification of Diseases (ICD), 9th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM) codes 992.0-992.9, E900.0 or E900.9. Cases admitted on or after October 1, 2015, are represented by the ICD, 10th Edition, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) codes T67, X30, X32. Cases with diagnoses represented by ICD-9-CM code E900.1 (if admitted before October 1, 2015) or ICD-10-CM code W92 (if admitted on or after October 1, 2015) were excluded. Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.

Because of the October 1, 2015 change in diagnostic codes from ICD-9-CM to ICD-10-CM, changes in numbers and rates over time should be interpreted with caution because they may be in part due to changes in the coding system.
Average population from ACS 5-year Estimate.

Each neighborhood receives a score from 1 (lowest risk) to 5 (highest risk) based on a statistical model that uses social and environmental factors to estimate risk of heat-related death across NYC neighborhoods. A low vulnerability score does not mean no risk. Every neighborhood has residents at risk for heat illness and death. Residents who are at highest heat risk are those who do not have or use air conditioning and are older or have chronic health conditions or serious mental illnesses.

The number of NYC residents admitted to a NYC hospital during the months of May-September summed over a 3-year period for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. The data also include patients admitted to the hospital after being treated in an emergency department.

The number of NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED, during the months of May-September summed over a 3-year period for the effects of heat and light due to weather conditions or undetermined cause. Residents with a diagnosis of excessive heat due to non-environmental conditions were excluded. Data are based on date of admission and include those who were admitted with a diagnosis of heat-related illness, even if that was not the principal diagnosis. Because ED visits can take place over multiple days, counts are dependent on the date chosen to reference the visit and could differ slightly from those based on date of discharge.

 

Numbers are summed by 3-year age groups and divided by the 3-year summed population in each age group, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates, to produce average annualized rates. Quotients are multiplied by the proportion of the 2000 US population in each age group. The average annual age-adjusted rate is the sum of the weighted age-specific rates; expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

Yearly bike availability is calculated by totaling average daily bike availability and dividing by the number of days in the year.
